I recommend really considering how you mesh with the people you will be working with, because your work style with your coworkers is very important in what you get out of working here. Overall pros: beautiful campus, nice people, university protects LGBTQ+ individuals (aka won’t fire them for just being LGBTQ+).

job_title: Marketing Analyst in State College, PA
pros: The workplace culture and benefits are amazing. Everyone that I have worked with has been extremely pleasant and respectful. Work-life balance is highly valued. You rarely work more than 40 hours/week, and get more paid days off than you can use. The retirement and health benefits are excellent as well. Overall, it is a low-stress job with great people.
cons: It takes forever to get any sort of substantial pay increase/promotion. I was hired 4 years ago and have increased my list of responsibilities and proficiencies far beyond an entry level position. Despite the recommendations from my managers and high performance reviews, the University can't or won't offer me a salary increase. This system is far from transparent and extremely frustrating. From the people that I have talked to, this is not an isolated case. Many (or even most) talented young professionals leave the University after a few years because their pay is not commensurate with the skills they acquire and the responsibilities they take on.

cons: Penn State has a huge network and offers lots of positions, however, all those departments are run by very different people. I primarily worked in the art/humanities sector of Penn State and that meant working with a lot a faculty. Even as a full time staff member (with a Master's Degree) I found most faculty to be hard to work with. They don't answer emails, but when they need something from you they don't hesitate to email you 6 times a day, call you, and reach out to your supervisor.

job_title: Assistant Research Professor in State College, PA
pros: Many domain-specific research facilities and resources. Penn State has its own supercomputer/high performance computing center and is positioning itself as hub for data science innovation in academia. The surrounding area has easy access to nature and outdoors activities. The college town is growing rapidly and attracts a surprising number of cultural events, given its size.
cons: Institutional culture is paranoid, rigid, traditional. I'd previously worked at a private university with ~13000 undergraduates and ~8000 graduate students, and at a public university with ~15000 undergraduates and ~2000 graduate students. Penn State, at ~45000 undergraduates and ~14000 graduate students, has the most red tape and bureaucracy by far. Geographically it's isolated, which is a con for many people (as a result, they have a decent policy on joint hires) but which I didn't mind.

job_title: Full Stack Developer in State College, PA
pros:
Penn State has really good benefits, solid 401K, good insurance, and tough to beat 75% off tuition. Penn State is so vast that you can move around departments and colleges to find a good fit for your skillset. 

Depending on which department you are at, you'll probably find there is no real top down mandate on what technology you use to accomplish your projects. This gives you a certain amount of autonomy.

Historically, we've had to use everything in-house, however, that is changing. There was recently an IT re-org where a cloud group and enterprise applications groups were created. Developers can now use cloud providers like amazon, microsoft and others.
cons:
Departments and colleges usually have their own IT staff which creates technology silos. This can make it difficult to integrate into existing university systems. Often developers that don't work in central IT feel they are working "on and island".

Some developers might find themselves working for managers who don't have an IT background which can create issues.

job_title: Lab Coordinator in University Park, PA
pros:
I was a graduate student at Penn State and then got hired for a part time position for a while. Penn State graduate student quality of life varies grreatly based on the department (some departments pay lower stipends than others). I was lucky to be in a department that supports students with an adequate stipend. 

Later, in my part time position, the only good thing about the part time job I got was that my colleagues (teaching professors) were very kind and treated me with respect. I liked the work I had to do but (read cons)
cons: the pay was very low and there are no opportunities for growth.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: The department I was in overall had a fantastic community. I say this based on positive experiences with the graduate student,body, the departmental secretaries, faculty, staff, and department head. They were extremely supportive during my time there especially when I ran into some funding issues during my final year.
cons: While my department was extremely supportive, I currently have the impression that the overarching university administration was impartial to any concerns or questions I raised and quick to fall back to regulation regardless of circumstances. In theory problems of this nature can be avoided on the graduate student end by proactively following due diligence and researching all graduate requirements well in advance of deadlines (ideally within their first semester). It bothers me however that I am unaware of any situation where a graduate student's (or even a faculty member's) circumstances were taken into account and an exception to any university rule was made.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in University Park, PA
pros: Great benefits and work/life balance. Most offices are very relaxed and lenient. This is the place to be for a relaxed life... and you get a lot of vacation time to use to make it even better.
cons: As a public institution there is already a big different between private industry pay and what PSU offers. But in the last ten years budget cuts have dropped PSU salaries way behind the industry. If you are from outside, coming in, and are fine with moving on to another place, you're good to go. You can negotiate for a good salary and you can leave for a new one if needed. Internal employees are constrained to 4% increases (before negotiation) on any job switch, even with a new degree or more responsibility.
